titlepage.titleproper:
Finding aid for
Jesse Gonzales papers
titlepage.author:
Finding aid created by
Olga Virakhovskaya, May 2014

did.unittitle: Jesse Gonzales papers 1968-2014 1982-2012
did.abstract: The papers of Jesse Gonzales document the Latino and Hispanic communities in Michigan, primarily within the Lansing area, and elsewhere. Materials include photographs, both analog and digital, as well as personal and biographical information about Gonzales and his family, his poetry and selected writings. Additionally, the papers contain printed materials about cultural and art programs and festivals in the state.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, Univeristy of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Collection donated by Jesse Gonzales (donor no. 10969) in August 2013 and April 2014.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open without restriction. Digital materials are accessible online only at the Bentley Historical Library.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan. Reproduction for commercial use requires permission from Jesse Gonzales.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Jesse Gonzales Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Native of Albion, Mich. Jesse Gonzales is a lifelong resident of the state. He has been photographing since his high school days. He received his B.A. in History with minor in Journalism from Michigan State University and M.A. in Community College Education from the University of Michigan (1979). Gonzales has also been active in historical documentation of Michigan Latino history. Beginning in the 1960s, while attending college, Jesse Gonzales and his wife Joana have amassed and saved a sizable collection of materials, publications, books, magazines, newspapers, photography art and artwork which documented the Chicano collegiate presence in East Lansing, Kalamazoo, and Ann Arbor, Mich.

During the late 1970s, Jesse Gonzales began exhibiting his photography along with other Latino artists in the Lansing, Mich. area. Several of his photographs were published in "500 years of Chicano History in Pictures" (Albuquerque, N.M.: SouthWest Organizing Project, 1991). Gonzales has photographed in Michigan, California, Illinois, Texas, Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic, Mexico and Spain. Besides his personal photographic endeavors, Gonzales worked with other Michigan Latinos, students and artists, to create one of the first statewide Latino arts organizations: The Raza Arts & Media Collective, founded in 1975.

One of his favorite photographic subjects is the Virgin of Guadalupe (the Virgin Mary), a figure revered by Mexicans and Chicanos throughout the U.S. He also continues search out signage, representations, figurines, symbols and icons that evoke Latinidad and Chicanismo. Gonzales is drawn to Chicano iconography that evokes the life and spirit of Latino neighborhoods, including graffiti, signage murals, and statuary. This resulted in the production of "El Calendario Hispano de Michigan, 1981." The calendar covered Hispanic social, cultural, political, and historical events in Michigan from 1781 to 1980.
As an educator Jesse Gonzales has worked for the Michigan State University, Michigan Department of Education, and Lansing School District.

arrangement.p: The collection is organized in to two series: Topical Files and Visual Materials

scopecontent.p: The Jesse Gonzales papers include original images created by Jesse Gonzales, as well as collected materials on Latino/Chicano life and culture in Michigan.

did.unittitle: Topical Files

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files series (1 linear foot) includes personal and biographical information about Gonzales and his family, his poetry and select writings, research notes, collected materials created by and about Michigan cultural and art institutions and artists, printed material about cultural and art programs and festivals in the state. Also a finding aid to the Juana and Jesse Gonzales papers at Michigan State University.

did.unittitle: Visual Materials

scopecontent.p: The Visual Materials series (0.1 linear feet, 7.7 GB online, and 1 oversize folder) includes images taken by Gonzales during Chicano/Latino cultural and art festivals, concerts, art exhibits, dances, religious ceremonies, public political gatherings. The majority of images were taken in galleries and on locations in Lansing, Lansing Community College and Michigan State University campuses, and other locations in greater Lansing, Mich. area. Images of murals and street art include those taken in Texas, California, and Mexico. Photographs include images of Gonzales family. Among outsize visual material one will find posters and flyers advertising art events, as well as outsize calendars, Michigan legislature resolutions, and two mounted color photographs.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Juana & Jesse Gonzales papers, 1960-2006 at Michigan State University. Collection contains 6 boxes of reports, newsletters, reprints, unpublished papers and news clippings collected by Jesse & Juana Gonzales since the late 1960's through 2006. A significant part of the collection dates from the mid-1960's through the mid-1980's and relates to Chicano student activism on campuses, Chicanos and Latinos in the arts, and materials on the history of Chicanos and Latinos in Michigan including agricultural labor and migrant workers.
